boardgame.name: A tale of pirates: a dummy mutiny
boardgame.description:
Steam page

Hai mai sognato di vestirti come un Pirata, parlare come un Pirata, sparare come un Pirata? Rendi tutto questo socialmente accettabile indossando le tue bende VR per gli occhi e mostrando a tutti chi è il capo. Voglio dire, il pirata numero uno.

Immagina di essere il capitano di una nave e della sua gioiosa ciurma; ora immagina che la ciurma, ehm, sia un branco di pupazzi. Pupazzi in collera, sull'orlo dell'ammutinamento.
Sta a te rimettere tutti al proprio posto, perciò afferra le tue pistole a pietra focaia e preparati ad affrontare la minaccia più insensata della tua carriera marinaresca.

ARCADE A PROFUSIONE
Punta, mira, spara - è semplicissimo. Ottieni punti per ogni pirata (duh, pupazzo) colpito, con un bonus addizionale per la distanza, i colpi alla testa e le combo, finché non rimane nessuno in piedi. E vedi di colpire anche i proiettili che ti vengono lanciati, se così possiamo definirli.

DAL MARE ALLE SPIAGGE
Sblocca 5 scenari di gioco differenti attraverso un sistema a missioni, poi rigioca il livello che desideri selezionandolo dalla tua cabina a bordo.

PUNTA ALL'OLIMPO PIRATESCO
Sfida gli amici che osano avventurarsi in casa tua a battere il tuo punteggio, o scala la classifica mondiale dei bucanieri più instancabili. Oppure segui diligentemente i tuoi doveri pirateschi e sblocca qualche luccicante achievement come premio.

Sei pronto a salpare? Il mare ti attende!"

REQUISITI DI SISTEMA
MINIMI:
Sistema operativo: Windows 7 SP1, Windows 8.1 or Windows 10
Processore: Intel® i5-4590, AMD FX 8350
Memoria: 4 GB di RAM
Scheda video: NVIDIA GeForce® GTX 970, AMD Radeon™ R9 290
Rete: Connessione Internet a banda larga
Memoria: 2 GB di spazio disponibile

CONSIGLIATI:
Sistema operativo: Windows 7 SP1, Windows 8.1 or Windows 10
Processore: Intel® Core i7-4790 or AMD Ryzen 5 1500X
Memoria: 8 GB di RAM
Scheda video: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1070 8GB / AMD RX Vega 56 8GB
Rete: Connessione Internet a banda larga
Memoria: 4 GB di spazio disponibile

boardgame.name: Marvellous Marketplaces
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Players of all kinds often find themselves visiting random shops when they're in any sort of town, requiring quick work from the Game Master. Here, with the Marvellous Marketplaces cards, we present you with the option to cut down on your work, when your players go "off the rails".

Each of the cards present a unique store, complete with a short description, the special goods that the store sells (beyond those a GM would normally assign to the store), and a unique little piece of information about the store, it's owner or a potential plot hook for the player characters to explore.

boardgame.name: Trinkets - Adventurers' Gear
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

How often do you really think about the gear your characters carry for the day-to-day business of being an adventurer? Sure, you have a backpack, and a lantern, and a ten-foot pole. You might have lockpicks, and torches, and rope. It's all functional, generic, and boring.

Trinkets - Adventurers' Gear aims to liven up the gear you carry, injecting some personality and intrigue to the mundane items you use in your adventures.

The Trinkets line is intended to inject more detailed descriptions, variety and flavour into your RPG worlds. The tables you'll find inside this book are system-agnostic, but work most easily in a fantasy setting.

Inside this download you will find:

tables full of new and unique trinkets that your players will be intrigued by every time they use them - and they'll use them a lot
over 100 unique and interesting pieces of adventuring gear ready to drop straight into your game, eash designed to add depth to your worlds and to provide interesting hooks for future adventures
adventure hooks, NPCs, and new locations to drop into your games

boardgame.name: Mad Dog Cards
boardgame.description:
Mad Dog Cards is a fun, family friendly game for 2-6 players from age 7+. Mad Dog Cards was created to increase awareness of how many animals are sad, lonely, and even "mad", awaiting a forever home. A "Mad Dog" represents a homeless or shelter dog.
Mad Dog Cards is a simple card game. The main objective is find a "Mad Dog" a home or owner. Players take turns drawing cards and completing up to 2 actions. If a "Mad Dog" card is drawn, player must find an owner. If the player can't find it a home or owner, that player loses. The winner is the last man standing.
Yellow personality cards are collected to swipe other players' cards or even retrieve cards from the discard deck. Action cards are used to stack the game in one's favor. One can choose to pick on a player and force their hand in playing a "Mad Dog." However, with a "Crazy Cat Lady" card, there is no telling how a setup will turn out!

boardgame.name: The Barbarian Reworked
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Putting the "reee" in Barbarian!

Second in the Winning Warrior series, the Barbarians Reworked improves the barbarian along the same lines as the Fighter Reborn, giving him a much-needed tune-up!

Much like the fighter, the barbarian takes a licking and keeps on kicking – but better than his armored counterpart. Resilience makes certain of that!

With the core mechanic of rage made into a more "per-battle" system, than a "per-day" one, the barbarian gains some additional longevity that the wizard and cleric just don't have!

Finally, the barbarian's rage powers are given their own fixing, in line with the new system of rage, allowing her to use them during a rage by giving up some of her rage duration!

Win the day – with a warrior!

Lots o' Loot: Magical Items for the Torchbearer RPG

A collaboration 15 years in the making between Jared A. Sorensen and John Wick.

Need some magical goodies for your Torchbearer game? Lots o’ Loot has got you covered with over 170 stones, gems, coins, charms, gloves and garments, curses, stones, weapons, relics and two enchanted codpieces (!) guaranteed to make your players drool with anticipation or quiver with fear.

A botanical bonanza of strange plants and fungi like Mindweed, Black Apples and Winter Roses!
Weird and gruesome artifacts like Ylfen’s Eye, the Golem Hand, the Grinding Balls, Jayvir’s Heart and the terrifying clockwork Winged Skull.
…and many more!

boardgame.name: Monkey: The Role-Playing Game - Quick Start Rules
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Monkey Quickstart rules is a short excerpt of the main rulebook, intended as a pickup and play introduction to the soon to be released Monkey the Role-Playing Game.

The Four Pilgrims from the Journey to the West. Meet Monkey, Pigsy, Sandy and Tripitaka, the three immortals and the mortal monk, Tripitaka, who are travelling from China to India in the West along a demon infested road. These are pre-generated characters from the book that you can pick up and play.
How to Play. A quick, concise version of the action system that is used for every situation where the immortals meet uncertainty and an element of risk. This section also explains how an adventure is put together using scenes and how players interact within this framework.
If you See Buddha on the Road. This short introductory adventure is suitable for both beginning players and Narrators. This adventure guides you gently through it, introducing key concepts of the setting and the rules in quickly absorb-able highlight boxes.
More Immortals. Another set of three immortals and the Nun that they are escorting to India, that demonstrate the sort of immortals that you can create using the full rules.

boardgame.name: Faerie Haven
boardgame.description:
"The Fast Fun Card game, designed by David Harmer (author of Aftermath! Technology!, Aftermath! Magic!, and Aftermath! Survival Guide). This single-deck card game is a quick to learn game for 2-6 players. Only 5 minutes to learn, but can be played for hours. Many of the cards change the game rules, but the details are printed on the card."

-- publisher description


From the publisher's former website, as of 2002:

" Faerie Haven Basic Deck - Faerie Haven is a Single Deck Card game for 2-6 players. The basic deck includes 78 cards, each with their own unique artwork, and a simple Rule Book. Price: $USD 12.00

Faerie Haven Limited Edition Expansion - The Faerie Haven Limited Edition Expansion is the first Faerie Haven Expansion Set! Originally produced for Chatton XXVII, the response was so well recieved we decided to offer them for sale! This Expansion adds 12 new cards each with their own unique artwork to the Faerie Haven Basic Deck (FH-012002s), and upgrades 3 Heroes and 1 Item. Only 2000 of these Limited Edition Expansions will be printed, so be sure and get your copy today! - Price: $USD 3.00

Faerie Haven Collectors Pack Volume 1 - The Faerie Haven Collectors Pack Volume 1 contains the Faerie Haven Basic Deck (FH-012002s) and the Limited Edition Expansion (Fh-012002CHE). Only 2000 Limited Editon Expansions will be printed, so be sure and get yours today! - Price: $USD 14.00 "


After the publisher Mushroom Circle Games shut down their website, this card game was then sold online through the Fantasy Games Unlimited website. The shrink-wrapped deck of cards had card backs marked "FH", and included the first expansion which adds new cards to the game.

boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

This full color battlemap is the 384th of a series featuring various terrains. This installment of the battlemap series features a snow covered forest landscape.

The map is 28 x 30 squares in size, with each 1 inch square scaled to represent 5 feet. It is provided in 12 segments, which need to be assembled, in a single PDF using the letter format.

The product has been updated to include a large gridless JPG image of the map, intended for use with VTT software. It is 2016x2160 pixels in size at 72dpi.

boardgame.name: TerraTech
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – AVAILABLE




This game is still in active development and available to the public for purchase in it's unfinished state, either in Early-Alpha or Beta (or any status in between).




The game has been available as Early Access since February 6th, 2015, but will be getting a full release on PC, Playstation 4, and Xbox One in the Summer of 2018.

From the game's website:

In TerraTech you design, construct and command a fleet of unique vehicles, as you battle your way to victory across the lawless frontiers of new alien worlds, in a quest for glory and profit.

In the distant future, Earth's natural resources have been depleted, and as an off-world prospector it's your job to travel to alien planets and scour them for valuable materials. These can be refined and shipped back to Earth in return for cash, or crafted into new components to augment your fleet.

The rarest resources unlock the best equipment, so expand your territory and capture enemy bases, to secure your position on each planet.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Attack of the Jelly Monster: Promotional Districts
boardgame.description:
FACE A: Cannes
Before scoring this district, reroll all the dice placed on this district. Use the new die results to determine the controlling player. As an exception, dice of the same color showing the same value do not cancel each other out after the reroll. The controlling player gains 2 Jelly, the second player gains 4, and the third player gains 7.

Before scoring this district, reroll all the dice placed on this district. Use the new die results to determine the controlling player. As an exception, dice of the same color showing the same value do not cancel each other out after the reroll. The controlling player gains 7 Jelly, the second player gains 4, and the third player gains 2.

FACE B: New York
The controlling player gains 4 Jelly for each die of their color showing an ODD number placed on this district. Dice showing an EVEN number are used to determine the controlling player but they are not worth any Jelly with this reward.

The controlling player gains 4 Jelly for each die of their color showing an EVEN number placed on this district. Dice showing an ODD number are used to determine the controlling player but they are not worth any Jelly with this reward.

boardgame.name: Distant Worlds: A Game of Interstellar Adventure
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

150 years after World War III...

Spacecraft from Earth and its colonies have ventured outward to a distance of twenty parsecs from home to find hundreds of alien worlds. Humanity has carved out a very small part of the universe to call its own, but also has discovered there are other sentient races out there as well – some friendly, some neutral, some isolationist and some downright hostile.

Space offers nearly infinite possibilities – both legal and not so. But come prepared, because the void is not a forgiving place. It takes a special breed to make it out in the black – tough, independent and cagey. They are exactly the kind of people who don’t do very well when hemmed in by rules, regulations and laws. They are the sorts of people who take risks every single day of their lives and call it an occupational hazard – and wouldn’t have it any other way.

Welcome to the universe of Distant Worlds!

boardgame.name: Legends of Signum: Battle for Vallor
boardgame.description:
It is a miniatures wargame and a collectible card game. Two players with the help of their heroes, characters and support cards fighting on the Battlefield. Also in the game presented economy system, before the battle you need to construct your own City(with help of building cards) and collect prosperity points, which helps to summon characters for battle, build terrains or ruins to disrupt opponent's plans and use different spells, tactics and relics to make your army completely great!

There are two possible win conditions in the game:
1) Warrior path: To defeat enemy Hero
2) Economy path: To accumulate necessary level of prosperity points(51)
Only you will choose your path, be warlike warrior or strategist, trying always to be one step ahead - all is up to you!

Squads of creatures fight under the leadership of Heroes.

First Edition - "Legends of Signum: Battle for Vallor" will immerse you into a fantasy world. There are represented two factions, which are in confrontation to each other, the Holy Grypharim Empire - this huge Empire inhabited by angel-like creatures Grypharims, the combination of human and griffins makes them a really skillful and powerful warriors, on the other hand the Free City Vallor - trading city, where representatives of various peoples from every corner of Signum have blended like in a melting pot. Here are possible any alliances, even between the most implacable enemies. You can also find the third part of the confrontation - mercenaries, they are neutral, but avid for gold and glory, so they are ready to join everyone who will pay.

On our Kickstarter you will find all the necessary for the game:

1) Starter Box "the Free City of Vallor" and Starter Box "the Holy Grypharim Empire" where you will find One Hero(Brissa de Molforn for Vallor and Roland the Proud for Grypharims), characters and cards with corresponding faction, dice, tokens and markers.
2) Core Box with both factions in one box includes everything in both starter sets + Battlefield.
3) Advanced Core Box with everything in Core Box + Four additional Heroes, 11 mercenaries,
high quality Battlefield, high quality prosperity coins.
4) Add-ons where you can purchase additional Heroes, characters, some miniatures of terrains and buildings, boosters rulesbook and more.
5) All-inclusive set (now in development)with everything in our Advanced Core Box including Add-ons.

Thanks to a team of excellent artists and sculptors, every miniature in the game has an original look and its own character.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: G-Core PRIME
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

What is G-Core?

G-Core is a simple set of rules for use in any genre. Spawned and updated for the modern gamer, G-Core roots come from the original Marvel Super Heroes or more famously known as FASERIP. This isn't the original FASERIP nor is it a product of Marvel Comics, but it is 99% compatible with it.

Things we've updated from FASERIP:


Talents have now become Special Focus
Instead of Fighting, Agility, Strength, Endurance, Reason, Intuition, and Psyche we now have: Rumble, Agility, Might, Moxie, Smarts, Perception and Spirit.
The tables are gone! After play testing using a simple ten-sided die, we found a better way to make resolutions! By doing this it became much more comic book than the previous incarnation.



Worried about real compatibility? We took a character from the old FASERIP game and changed it to G-Core in less than 20 seconds!

What changed in Prime?

New ORIGIN and HERO TYPE rules for awesome character creation.

Streamlined powers, with less reference back into the book. Add to that complete overhauls on other areas to make the book look clean and easy to use!

boardgame.name: Exodus: Paris Nouveau
boardgame.description:
Your mission? Lead a daring rescue attempt to save innocent citizens from the corrupted Paris Nouveau government. You've been in this together from the beginning. You've had each other's backs, but we fear some of your team may have been bought off by the hunters — especially since our last team didn't come back. Trust no one but yourself!

In Exodus: Paris Nouveau, you're a member of a specialist team sent on a rescue mission to save refugees trapped in an urban warzone. At the start of the game, the players are secretly and randomly divided into two teams: those with a secret hunter ID card are on the hunters team, and those with a secret rescuer ID card are on the rescuers team. The problem is that although you know which team you're on, you don't know which of the other players are also on your team and which are on the other team!

Further, in Exodus: Paris Nouveau, you win or lose as a team. Throughout the game, you use abilities, deduction, and guesswork to determine your team members, and together strive to win as a team. The game may end in a number of ways:


If a player has no life tokens, the game immediately ends. That player reveals their secret ID card and their team loses, resulting in a win for the other team.
The hunters win (and the rescuers lose) immediately if no cover tokens remain in the game.
The hunters win (and the rescuers lose) immediately if the total hunter distance (i.e., the sum of the distance values on all face-up cards in the hunter line) equals or exceeds the total rescuer distance (i.e., the number of distance tokens remaining in the game plus the sum of the distance values on all face-up cards in the rescuer line).
If the game hasn't ended beforehand, it concludes at the end of the seventh round. In this case, the rescuer's team score is the number of victory point icons on the face-up cards in the rescuer line (i.e., each running figure symbol is worth one victory point), and the hunter's team score is the number of victory point icons on the face-up cards in the hunter line. Whichever team has the higher score wins.
If scores are tied, continue playing rounds until either an immediate-win condition has been met or at the end of a round one team has a higher score than the other, at which point they're declared the winning team.

boardgame.name: Tarzan Lord of the Jungle
boardgame.description:
Lord of the Jungle is a cooperative game for 1 to 4 players that can be played in 60 to 90 minutes.

In this thematic adventure game, you play as Tarzan, Jane, and their allies. Lay out cards to create a map of Africa, and then fight your way across the map to reach the lost city of Opar! Each map card that you choose in your journey reveals your next encounter. Each encounter pits you against a specific tile layout, and an assortment of enemies and interactive 3D trees. Fight enemies by using your equipment cards and rolling dice.

Be careful to keep Tarzan and Jane out of danger. If either of them perish, the game is lost! If you're able to fight through the scenarios and make your way to Opar, all that's left in front of you is a final boss fight. Work together and take down the boss to win the game!

-description from designer

The world is crumbling. The Swarm has corrupted the Coalition’s robot army and is descending upon human cities. With danger closing in, Kait Diaz breaks away to uncover her connection to the enemy and discovers the true danger to Sera – herself.

ESCAPE
Outrun the bomb, outsmart the Swarm, and escape the Hive! Escape is a new, aggressive, high-stakes co-op mode featuring a three-player suicide squad that must work together to take out enemy hives from within.*

VERSUS
May the best team win! Rack up points and trade up for superior weapons in Arcade, a frenetic playlist built for jump-in, over-the-top fun. With ten other game types plus new and classic maps, Versus rewards every competitive style, from casual to pro.*

HORDE
Can you and four friends endure waves of ever-stronger enemies and bosses? Survive using new hero abilities, building defenses, collecting power, leveling up your skills and working as a team.*

MAP BUILDER
Create custom Escape hive maps and experiences to share with and challenge your friends.

ACCESSIBILITY
Customize your gaming experience with updated accessibility features, including: full controller remapping, single stick movement, Adaptive Controller support, narrated UI and menus, improved subtitles and more.

FEATURES

THREE-PLAYER CAMPAIGN CO-OP

TOURS OF DUTY

VISUAL SHOWCASE
Play every mode in 4K and HDR at a smooth 60 frames per second on Xbox One X.

BOOTCAMP

boardgame.name: Ultraverse Roleplaying System
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Ultraverse is a fast-paced system designed to create superheroic, fantasy, science fiction and countless other types of adventures for players. Each player assumes their own role as a character in each campaign that the Gamemaster creates. Ultraverse is designed to emulate the fictional powers and abilities found in the pages of four-color comic books, the sword and sorcery powers and settings of fantasy novels and movies as well as the high-tech weapons and abilities of science fiction books and movies. Polyhedral dice such as d20, d12, d10, d8, d6 and d4 are required for play in Ultraverse. Hexagonal or Square maps are useful but not required for playing.

User summary:

Ultraverse is advertised as "compatible with" d20 System, though there are some significant differences.

boardgame.name: Zombie Apocalypse
boardgame.description:
Zombie Apocalypse is a light roll-and-move game in which you must navigate through a building filled with zombies and escape to safety.

At the start of the game, a gun is randomly placed on the board via die roll and 6 zombies are placed in the indicated starting positions. You move by rolling a dice and moving that number of squares on the board - which can be diagonal or orthogonal movement. The zombies also move by die roll with each result indicating the direction they'll move.

If you're able to find the gun you can shoot the zombies, but otherwise you must just carefully avoid them and try to reach the bomb shelter on the far side of the board.

boardgame.name: Shadowrun: Sprawl Ops
boardgame.description: Shadowrun: Sprawl Ops is a competitive game for 2 to 4 players that can be played in 60 to 90 minutes. In this cyber-punk worker-placement game, each player controls a team of Shadow Runners that they can send on missions, loan to other players (for a fee, of course), and upgrade with new tech and equipment. Missions are resolved by rolling combinations of custom dice. A diverse team of Shadow Runners gives you access to more combinations of dice, and your upgrades add even more dice to your pool. Take on smaller missions to earn creds. Then, put those right back into more experienced runners, and better gear. Once you think you've got what it takes, send your runners out to attempt to collect one final score. If you fail, don't worry, your doc-wagon contracts will keep your runners in the game. The first player to successfully complete the final mission, and collect that last big score wins the game!

boardgame.name: Halloween
boardgame.description:
In Halloween, each player is a monster trying to be the first to capture a human in the center of the board. The game uses a simple roll and move mechanic to advance along the track, but if you hit a space with a dot in it, you will have to draw a card - which could send you a certain number of spaces forward or backward.

Each card has instructions for each monster on it. You will just read the instruction relevant to you. If you run out of cards, shuffle the discard pile to form a new draw deck.

The first player to reach the center of the board is the winner!

boardgame.name: You Are The Hero: A History of Fighting Fantasy Gamebooks
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's website:

Fighting Fantasy gamebooks have sold over 17 million books worldwide, in over 30 languages. But when Steve Jackson and Ian Livingstone sat down to write The Warlock of Firetop Mountain they had no idea this one book would go on to spawn another eighty or more titles, and have an immeasurable impact on a generation of children growing up in the 1980s.
Part history, part celebration, YOU ARE THE HERO chronicles more than three decades of Fighting Fantasy. Written by Jonathan Green (author of seven Fighting Fantasy titles), this mighty tome will appeal to anyone who ever wiled away a washed-out summer holiday with only two dice, a pencil, and an eraser for company.

boardgame.name: TOPPEN
Tower of Babel
バベルの塔
boardgame.description:
バベルの塔 ("Tower of Babel"), also known as TOPPEN, is played with ten tiles — five black and five red — with each player taking one color. During set-up, the second player places the ten tiles face down randomly in a square grid so as to form a continuous shape of their choice. The tiles are flipped color-side up, then the game begins. Taking turns, players take one of their tiles and place it on top of a neighboring tile/stack. The following restrictions apply:


You can take only one tile, the topmost of a stack.
You cannot split the tiles into two separate groups.
You cannot move a tile to an empty space.


If you cannot make a legal move, you must pass until a legal move is available to you again. You cannot pass if a move is available.

The goal is to have your own tile at the top of the last pile remaining when the game ends.

boardgame.name: The Veiled Council of Yzeem (Pathfinder)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The monarchs and rulers of the Known Lands are heroes and villains of the highest order, known far and wide for their deeds as well as their character, or lack thereof. In the nation of Yzeem, however, those who hold power rule in anonymity, but out of necessity, not desire. The Veiled Council was convened to free Yzeem from corruption and criminal influence, and it is a system that has prospered for centuries.

Each of the seven members of the Veiled Council has certain responsibilities and commands their own forces, each with its own focus and requirements. Within these pages you will learn what is known about each of the Councilors and what manner of agents they employ, which can lend itself to player involvement in a campaign.

boardgame.name: Incandium's Eruption, Saatman's Empire (3 of 4) (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A 5th Edition compatible adventure for four to six PCs of level 14.

Incandium’s youth was fairly typical, at least for a half-dragon raised amongst dragons, filled with years of endless physical and mental abuse. It was always clear he was different than his clutch-mates, though his mother only claimed it was because he was ‘special’, never explaining what latent power his elemental blood held. And so, after studying magic and drawing on untold power, he slew his mother and claimed control over the volcano he called home, which he has ruled with an iron fist ever since. Now, however, he sees the PCs as a threat to his plans, and he calls them to the field of battle! Even if he is defeated, can the party stop his machinations to unleash a wave of dragons on Klavek’s western border?

Also included in “Incandium’s Eruption”:

A new magic item, the bracer of shields
Two new alchemical solutions, azure powder and engraving solution
A new spell, redirect teleport
A new deity, Hado, the god of summer and judgment
Details on Elemental Princes, and the blessings and curses they can bestow on characters
Details on the Serpins Sanguis cult, including their origins and goals

boardgame.name: Book of Exalted Darkness (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A massive 414 page vile grimoire woven throughout a glorious tome of resplendent holy gold and luxury!

This is THE book for evil in 5th Edition!

Yet the Book of Exalted Darkness is more than just that, paired beside a holy decopunk campaign setting (think Rocketeer or Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow) for players to destroy or subvert.

Centuries ago the Celestial Heroes emerged from the Twilight of Suffering, leading the peoples of Askis through the ages to the bright utopian future of today. Their great works enrichen the world, the institutions they begat maintain order, and the gift of inaequa has changed the very face of civilization—machinery powered by the divine gift has urbanized society and the resulting radiation lengthens the lives of creatures good of heart.

Evil is dying out. Those of a malevolent bent are treated by The Ministry's sanitariums and when they cannot be rehabilitated sent to the Samovi Preserve to live out the rest of their shorter lives among other foul beings. The empathic Justitia roam about Askis guarding against criminals, and for the few heretics that persist The Inquisition has agents everywhere. On the eve of ridding all of Askis of corruption however, a grand ploy by the most despicable mad scientists lurking below the surface has taken hold!

The Night of Largitio terrified the populace of the world but seemed only an anomally, only now bearing its horrible fruit: you. Before you were conceived destiny bestowed an inherent heresy on your soul, forever corrupting your very destiny. All of the bureaucracy that once served to occupy the people of Askis now bursts at the seams as you and your kind proliferate, and in turn the church-state has redoubled its efforts to contain the seeds of evil spreading across the globe.

Your maleficent benefactors — the mad scientists that instilled the flaw in your soul — are your most powerful allies against the theocracy arrayed against you, but with their aid you may well succeed where all others have failed. Better yet, with the assistance of the many dark powers that entreat you certainly the vaunted demigods protecting Askis could not stand against you. Indeed, yes, yes, for the powers of the nether draw from a well never-ending, and the fools before you that attempted to make these gifts their own were simply weak.

Not like you.

A few highlights include:

Sanctity and Sin, two new thematic attributes that evil PCs use to manipulate the strange technology of Askis (either tricking machines or perverting them!) and gain an edge on their do-gooder enemies!
Inherent Heresies! Askis has the standard races for Fifth Edition plus aasimar, and this new element of character creation colors how a villainous adventurer interacts with the world at large.
The theocratic world of Askis! From the Contiguous Continent to the Escarion Maelstrom and back there are over three dozen cities (each with their own saints) to tear down into rubble.
Three classes: the mad scientist, the diabolist, and the occultist. Take hold of technology, use the original iteration of the 5E master conjurer, or the first rendition of adventurers devoted to transforming themselves into monsters (and if yours isn't on the list below, try the dark transformation prestige class!)
Evil backgrounds and archetypes for every class. Join the Circle of Necrobotany, take the Oath of Heresy, submit to your fury as a Feral Rager, feed your ravenous patron the Meat, utilize the power of dark chi, and much more!
Nearly 50 feats ranging from grafting on monster parts to rituals for infant-skin cloaks to voodoo!
A whole new school of Vile magic including spells by James Introcaso and Savannah Broadway. Fling bone spurs, conjure a sanguine razorstorm, inflict unbearable pain, and much worse!
Equipment galore. Looking for some drugs? Augmetics? Maybe a jetpack or some power armor? Got the coin for one of those newfangled motorized inaequa-chariots? Or maybe you want to get at some of James' amazing evil relics!
20 pages for Evil Gamemastering including the very important discussion of consent between players and the GM, tips on how to keep a group of villainous adventurers from destroying each other, a system for handling trouble at the table, all of the poisons (including a great two page table summarizing each!), a bank of diseases, and more types madness for a deranged game.
6 unique mad scientists (master villains with lair actions!), their lieutenants, and three dozen creatures and NPCs counted among the forces of darkness. They are joined by over 50 NPCs and monsters amidst the Forces of Light focused around builds for bards, fighters, rogues, sorcerers, paladins, rangers, clerics, monks, and wizards of 4th, 8th, 12th, 16th, and 20th level (in total well over 100 new statblocks and templates for GMs!)
Two adventures! The Killing the Golden Twins module to get your evil campaign in Askis off to a wicked start and the scaling Searching the River Styx adventure for when PCs find themselves headed to the afterlife — perhaps escaping the underworld to live once more.

In NLT (No Later Than), all players have three Blokus-like tridimensional pieces: a N, a L and a T. Each round, a card is drawn, indicating a top, a front and a side view, as well as two of the three pieces. The object of the game is to use the two pieces indicated in order to build a structure matching the three views. The game ends as soon as a player has 4 points. They are declared the winner.

boardgame.name: Joker Go
boardgame.description:
Joker Go is a Go variant/expansion using a special deck of cards. Each player has an identical deck of 27 cards which show a configuration of Go stones. In the basic game players choose to either play a stone normally or randomly draw and play a Joker Go card. When you play a Joker card, you place the stones shown on the card onto the board in a spot of your choosing. In the advanced variant you either play a stone normally, draw three Joker Go cards or play a Joker Go card.

A Joker Go card can completely change the board state, making a lost group safe or killing an unkillable group. The potential for multiple stones to suddenly appear on the board subverts player's conventional understanding of the game of Go. It forces players to think about shapes in a new way.

The basic game adds a very random element where you are challenged to make do with a random Joker Go card as best you can. They are powerful, but the shapes you need may not be the shapes you draw.

In the advanced variant you have some flexibility as you have a choice of cards you can play. Having a hand of cards also gives you some strategic goals. You can play in a way that will make your hand cards more valuable. Your opponent has to worry that the "odd" moves you are making will set up a devastating Joker Go card down the line.

boardgame.name: AARU
boardgame.description:
In AARU players take on the role of one of the great and powerful Egyptian deities trying to draw worthy souls to their particular celestial palace in the Field of Reeds. To gather souls the gods play a game called AARU. Souls are won by winning tricks.

The souls of the Pharaohs are the most sought after by the gods. To win a Pharaohs soul you must deduce the value of one hidden card you own! Every time a player plays a card that could have been the Pharaoh card the opponents shout AARU!

AARU is a trick-taking deduction game for 2 to 4 players aged 8+. Each game takes 15 to 30 minutes to play.

GAME OVERVIEW

A game of AARU is played over 3 rounds and points are scored by winning tricks and by deducing and playing your Pharaoh card at the right time! Points can be lost if a Pharaoh is played incorrectly.

At the start of each round the players are dealt a hand of cards. All players pick a Pharaoh for the opponent to their left and add it to the opponents hand facing away from them.

In turn, players play a card from their hands with the highest value of the leading type played winning unless a Power card has beaten it. The twist is that in AARU whenever a player could have played their Pharaoh card (the one that faces away from them) the other Players say AARU to them to indicate they missed the chance of playing their Pharaoh. This way they can eventually deduce when is the best time to play their Pharaoh card for bonus points!

Points are totaled for each of the three rounds with the winner being declared by having the most points at the end.

boardgame.name: Hex Kit
boardgame.description:
From the publishers website:

Hex Kit is a multi-platform, lightweight desktop application for quickly and effortlessly building hex maps for your table top role playing games. We've built this application to have an emphasis on tile variety, art, and usability at the table.

Variety: Hex Kit was built around the original Hex Kit Volume One: Fantasyland, a collection of over 1,100 hand-illustrate map tiles. In the original kit instead of having one tile per terrain style or icon type, there is dozens of illustrations for different categories. Rather than painting a desert by repeating the same dune tile, you can paint a desert with flat tiles, dune tiles, palm trees, and oases. You can even mix in plateaus, cacti, and briar patches from the badlands tile set. The desktop application will automatically paint a random assortment of tiles from each category without the user needing to pick the individual tiles.

Hex Kit also allows the you to cherry-pick, or select a range of tiles from categories to randomly paint. Also included are tools to flip, rotate, and layer tiles on top of one another for maximum variety. On top of the ability to create rich, varied maps you can also use the powerful, custom map generator to take what little hard work there is out of making maps.

boardgame.name: Siege!
boardgame.description:
In Siege!, one player controls an army that is attacking a castle and trying to capture the other player's king. The other player is defending.

Pieces in the turn are placed upside-down to hide their values. Each player has 10 pieces ranging in value from 1 to 4. The king is placed on a marked square on the far side of the board. Each turn, the players choose one piece and move it one square orthogonally (there is no diagonal) movement in the game.

When a piece moves adjacent to an opponent piece, the values of both are revealed and the lower one is removed. There are also "trap" units which will automatically eliminate any unit they are adjacent to.

The game ends when the defending king is captured or when the the invaders run our of pieces.

Tactical trading and travel game for 2 to 6 people.

The players each receives a colored ship owner (character) and the appropriate charge! The locomotion occurs with a W6 in five trades.
The shipowner can buy ships in cash or on credit on his train, the ship arrives at the home port of the corresponding area.

There are various instructions on "telex" cards, which means: "travel" the voyages from port to port and "round trips" the voyages from the home port to a destination port and back to the home port.
Only fully loaded ships can travel, if they are not fully loaded, they will cost you a "mooring fee" every time the player rolls a dice!

If you have his charge (you get this in certain fields of the orbit!) Completely, then the color chips are turned with the closed side up.
The shipowner and all his loaded ships move forward after rolling the dice with the thrown number on all their ways.
Ships can be bought or sold in their home port, and the area of use can also be changed.

A charter ship and the possible meetings of the ships in the same fields bring some additional options in the game.
You agree on the end of the game at a certain time, who then has the highest total amount wins the game.

boardgame.name: India
boardgame.description:
In India, you and an opponent are trying to retrieve a dagger and bring it to the Taj Mahal. You will move along a path using a Carrom style flipping mechanic to determine how far you can move.

Each turn, the players will flip a chip in a box that is filled with numbered squares. The chip must bounce off the far wall and (hopefully) land on one or more of the squares. Your opponent will then look and the squares covered and decide which value you will move. You may choose to move forward or backward on the path.

There is only one dagger in the game. To capture it, you must land on it by exact count. You may also steal it from your opponent if you land on his or her piece.

The path is marked with yellow squares which give special events and shortcuts along the path. The first player to carry the dagger and land by exact count on the Taj Mahal is the winner.

boardgame.name: Children of the Fall
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In Children of the Fall, the players play as the sole survivors of an apocalypse that has turned all the adults on the planet into evil, bloodthirsty savages known as the fallen. As a group, the players will explore and develop the world and story together in a completely collaborative system. Players will need to keep an eye on the ever shifting hierarchy of their tribe, build and grow their haven and do the jobs that need doing to ensure the tribe’s survival. Agency is shared amongst the players, and the game uses a brand new streamlined and simple rule set, which keeps all the players engaged in every scene.

Children of the Fall is designed for 3-5 players. It is a GMless story game. Sessions take 120-240 minutes to complete. Unlike many traditional story games, Children of the Fall has support for one shot and campaign styles of play.

boardgame.name: Kingdom
boardgame.description:
Kingdom is a solitaire game. The rightful king has been killed by a usurper. You are a farmboy who is determined to get revenge for your beloved king.

You must travel to several different areas of the kingdom and solve problems for the inhabitants there. By doing this, you can eventually raise a mercenary army to overthrow the usurper.

Typically, the game uses a pickup and deliver mechanic. You will identify what the inhabitants of a certain area of the Kingdom need, and then find and bring that item to them. (You need to remember what they need since there is no reminder when you leave their area.)

The game does not use typical movement rules. You are free to travel from anywhere in the kingdom to anywhere in the kingdom on your turn.

You win the game by raising the mercenary army and moving into the castle.

boardgame.name: Part-Time Gods (2nd Ed.)
Part-Time Gods Second Edition
PTG2E
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Long ago, an entity known as the Source visited humanity and gifted certain people with divine power. For a time, the world existed in a state of balance between order and chaos, between life and death, between divinity and mortality. That is, until the gods waged war against the Source and eventually against each other, until the gods were close to extinct.

The gods of today are shadows of what the old gods possessed. Their power has been heavily diminished, and many choose to live a regular, mortal life, revealing themselves as gods only when absolutely necessary. The reason for this is twofold. First, fate doesn’t like it when the gods share their secrets with a mortal. Unless they are the god’s worshipper, terrible events and horrific accidents have a way of happening to the people closest to the god. Secondly, divine works attract creatures and monsters called Outsiders, created by the Source (after its capture) to destroy any god they encounter.

And so, the gods exist today in a state of flux. They have a mortal life, a job (or career if they’re lucky), friends, family, and everything that comes with being human, and they work hard to protect these things from harm. On the other side of the coin, they also have a Dominion to command and oversee, a deific Territory to defend from intruders, secret societies to which they owe allegiances (called Theologies), and other gods in their pantheon to try to get along with. This becomes their life, the balancing of the mortal and the divine, the normal and the supernatural, the mundane and the strange. The gods belong not to either world completely, and each of them knows that delving too deeply into one means losing pieces of the other.

Part-Time Gods Second Edition (PTG2E) is the latest iteration of an amazing setting about gods and the people, groups, and places in their lives that keep them tied to their humanity. This game gives players the tools to create their own gods and go on to tell dramatic, exciting, and engaging stories — the kind only PTG2E can deliver.

Part-Time Gods Second Edition has specialized chapters to help readers access the info in its pages with ease. Here is what to expect from each chapter.

Chapter One - The Descending Storm: This chapter details the setting of PTG2E, laying out divine origins and what it means to be a god in today’s world.
Chapter Two - The Spark of Divinity: Contains the rules for making characters, elaborating on the mortal and divine choices players have at their disposal to make just the god they want.
Chapter Three - Divine Expressions: Divine magic is a powerful tool, and this chapter explains how to use it to protect what they care about and become an even more powerful god.
Chapter Four - Blessing the Dice: This chapter gives an in-depth review of all the important rules needed to run a game of PTG2E. It’s a must-read for GMs, but a good one for players to read as well.
Chapter Five - Divine Battles: This chapter details what happens when gods collide, including battles, healing, and weaponry.
Chapter Six - The Opposition: No game is complete without antagonists to oppose the players and their characters. This chapter contains all these amazing foes and rules for running them in the game.
Chapter Seven - Creating New Myths: If you are curious about exactly how to run a game like PTG2E, look no further than this chapter.
Appendix: Includes blank character sheets, territory grid, random character creation charts, and an index

boardgame.name: No Marm, No Foul
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

So, you've agreed to run a game today and you have not had time to even think about an adventure. Don't freak out. We have you covered. This document is all that you need. Run this adventure. It will be over in one session. Then you can get back to your own evil machinations next session.

Standing somewhat isolated on the High Plains is a small town that was founded by a group of Irish immigrants. Over time, people from other ethnic groups have settled in Kilflor. This troubles some of the original founders, who want to keep the town a haven for the Irish coming to America. Today only a minority of the citizens care about their original ancestry. As a result, the Irish purists have grown alarmed and desperate.

To make matters worse, Kilflor now lives under a curse. No children have been successfully born to the residents for well over five years. Pregnancies terminate or babies are stillborn. Those with superstitious leanings blame the curse on a dead school marm. The teacher was driven to suicide when her class died during a Cholera epidemic. Given that she was of English ancestry, many believe the harassment that the school marm received from the Irish purists drove her to take her own life.

While this adventure is set in the Boot Hell campaign setting, it can easily be used in any sort of Western steampunk or horror roleplaying game. It uses 5th Edition SRD rules as a default.

Only a fool would go out there with the Indians on the warpath.

boardgame.name: Wok Star (3rd Edition)
boardgame.description:
Wok Star is a cooperative real-time game in which players take on different roles to help grow a Chinese restaurant in a tycoon style game. The clientele of customers is represented by a deck of cards with various Chinese dishes on them. Customers are served one at a time while a 30-second sand timer is running.

Each order requires a combination of ingredients to make. The board is used for tracking the levels of ten prepared ingredients in the kitchen. To prepare more ingredients, players spend dice in different combinations. All players are in charge of different tasks and all must work simultaneously because the timer is running!

At the end of each round, players pool their money and invest in different options to grow their business: acquire new recipes, upgrade preparation cards, or send out coupons to get more customers. The players must have a certain level of profit by the last round to keep the restaurant open and win!

The third edition of Wok Star contains new gameplay wrinkles: You can re-roll dice by "washing dishes" and modify dice by using "hustle". Fortune cubes limit how often you can share dice, and you now have daily goals that you must reach each round or else you lose immediately.

Publisher Blurb:

Taverns and inns are staples of fantasy settings. Characters meet up there, find adventures, speak to contacts and occasionally even get food, drinks or accommodation. boardgame.name: Baketage Museum
バケタージュ美術館
boardgame.description:
To get out of Baketage Museum (バケタージュ美術館), you must first free the four ghosts that are guarding the exits — and to do that, you must find the paired objects where these ghosts have placed their spirit.

To set up the game, create the stage inside the game box, then place your phone in the stage once you've downloaded the app needed for the game. Place the cards in a circle around the stage, then place each of the playing figures on a separate card.

On a turn, you roll the die, then move your figure the indicated number of spaces in either direction. You then take the card you've landed on and any other card in the circle and you hold those cards near your face within view of the phone's camera. The app reads the image on the back of each card and transforms each half of your face in some way. Perhaps your left eye grows to an enormous balloon, while your right eye curls like a rainbow. If the cards don't transform your face in the same eye, you return them to their places in the circle, with everyone else remembering what they saw on your face. Perhaps they should tell a story about what the objects you saw in the museum and why they made you look that way.

If you don't make a match, you lose one of your life tokens, and if someone runs out of tokens, you lose the game. If you do find a match, then great! Remove those cards from play. You're one step closer to escaping the museum.

The app randomizes which cards have which effects each game.

boardgame.name: Pirates of Penryn
boardgame.description:
Sail your rum from your huge galleon down shallow tidal Cornish waters using your small cramped RumRunner boat. You must make several trips back and forth to port, re-loading your limited RumRunner hand with the best combination of rum, crew and florin cards. Changing winds and tides affect which areas of the board are navigable and how far you can sail on each turn. The waters are also full of whirlpools that can twist your fortunes for good as well as ill. Other players can set the local seamonster upon you to cause trouble, or sail abreast to start a skirmish with their ferocious or charming crew and steal your profits. The player who successfully stows the most florins safely aboard their galleon (and has a decent crew to defend them) claims victory.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Combat HQ
boardgame.description:
Combat HQ is a set of World War Two miniatures wargame rules.
The game features seven combat missions and a campaign system. Also included are started battlegroups for late war German, Commonwealth, Soviet and US forces.

GAME FACTS
Game Length: 2-3 hours.
Unit Scale: The Platoon is the basic unit in the game and is represented by a model vehicle, infantry or gun.
Ground Scale: 1” equals 50 yards.
Figure Scale: Plays equally well with 2mm, 6mm, 10mm, 15mm and 20mm figures. 28mm figures are possible, but a large table is required.
Bases: No bases are required for vehicles. If you have based vehicle models, just make all measurements to the vehicle chassis and ignore the bases.

boardgame.name: Inside the Cup Golf
boardgame.description:
Inside the Cup is a simulation of the sport of golf using PGA Tour players and courses.

The development of the game started as a spinoff of the old Avalon Hill Golf game and then blossomed into something all its own. The stats the PGA tour keeps are much more detailed than ever before allowing for players to really show their strengths and weaknesses on golfer cards. Golfers are rated for driving length and accuracy. The cards show the golfers’ ability to hit greens from all distances along with proximity to the hole. Scrambling shots from the sand or around the green are captured as well as putting ability for distance and keeping away from the 3 putt.

Courses are depicted in colorful segments showing the good and the bad places on each hole. As shots are hit they end up in quadrants on the course that show the next club that will need to be used. Stay in the fairway and your next shot should be easier and hold better on the green. Hitting out of the rough or worse can make the shot to the green harder and might not hold up like you like. You don’t want to be too far off the green as those areas could spell danger, while around the green shows safer chip shots or bunkers to hit out of. Some greens even have adjustments that make them easier to hole out or some are more likely to bring out a 3 putt.

Gamers can just let the golfers’ golf or you can have some strategic decisions to make. Should I hit a little less club onto this narrow fairway? Go for it on this par 5? Should I go pin hunting or just play it safe to the middle of the green? Should I putt aggressively or just lag it up there and get off this green?

There are even ways to quick play the game. You can go hole by hole or finish a round with one roll of the dice. ITCG is a fairly fast playing game that can allow a gamer to take his favorite golfers out on some of his favorite courses without leaving his own table.

boardgame.name: Dungeon Slayer
boardgame.description:
Dungeon Slayer is a 1-4 player, fully cooperative, card game of dungeon crawling adventure. Each player will assume the role of an iconic hero, who, through the strategic use of an action deck unique to that hero, will delve into ancient ruins, hidden enemy strongholds, and sanctums of mystical power. There the heroes will face increasingly numerous and deadly enemies as they venture into ever more dangerous chambers in their quest to defeat a deadly foe, recover a long lost relic, or other bold deed.

Dungeon Slayer is unique from other dungeon crawlers in that it makes no use of miniatures or tiles, relying solely on the placement of hero and adversary cards to define the space of the passage or alcove in which combat occurs. This makes Dungeon Slayer easily portable and quick to set-up, while still preserving the feel of a heroic quest.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Building Blocks
boardgame.description:
Who doesn’t love building blocks? In this cooperative game 2-5 players try to build four perfect towers.

Each tower has a different color and is built by playing cards of that color in the right order. The players start the round by choosing the build order. Then, the players try to add cards from their hands to the towers. If they can't, they have to discard a card. Based on the discards of the last player, new cards are divided over the players.

Play continues until the first player runs out of cards. The final score is based on the height of the created towers. While only limited communication is allowed, the players cooperate to get the highest score.

boardgame.name: Inkarumi
boardgame.description:
Inkarumi ("Stone of the king") is a roll and write game in which the players aim to be the first to fill their entire pyramid of 21 fields. Six sixes are needed for the bottom row, five fives for the next, etc., with one one topping off the pyramid.
On a turn, a player rolls six dice only once and can check off all fields that are supported by two fields in the row below. However, if they roll more of a number than the row supports, they cannot fill that row. When a player rolls the exact dice to finish their pyramid, they have to yell "Inkarumi". If another players yells first, they roll is forfeit. Anyone who calls out "Inkarumi" in error has to delete some previously filled fields. The first player to completely fill their pyramid is the winner.

boardgame.name: Chai
boardgame.description:
In Chai, you will step into the shoes of a tea merchant, combining tea flavours to make a perfect blend. Specializing in either rooibos, green, oolong, black or white tea, you will buy and collect ingredients to fulfill your customers’ orders.

As a tea merchant, each turn you will do one of the following: Visit the Market, Select Additives, Reserve a Customer.

At the end of each turn, a player may complete a tea order from one customer card in their hand or visible in the customer pool. A base tea token, tea flavours and additives shown on the card are needed ingredients, and placed in an empty tea cup. The player flips over a tip and receives a coin bonus, moving the thermometer round tracker up one notch if all cups are filled.

The game ends when five rounds of cups have been fulfilled. When the final order is completed, other players complete their last turn so that each player has played the same number of turns.
To score, players add up their victory points from fulfilled customer orders, and add their leftover money to this total. In 3-5 player games, additional points are awarded to the player(s) who fulfilled the most orders and most diverse tea recipes. Award ties are friendly with each winner receiving 5 points.

The player with the most victory points (from customer orders, money, and awards) wins the game as best tea merchant! In the case of a tie, the person with the least number of fulfilled customer cards wins. If still tied, the person with the least amount of money wins. If that does not break a tie, the victory is shared.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Rawkahh! Launch
boardgame.description:
To win the game by leaving the planet with most points before the meteor hits the planet!

Each player gets 6 game cards and an action card, while the crystals are store in the tin

Depending on how many players are playing, 2-5 game cards will be dealt in the center

All players can choose to scavenge for materials or raid other player’s warehouse by showing their action card altogether
Players that are aiming for the same card during scavenging needs to battle each other to win the card
There are 3 mini games to choose for battle!

At the diplomacy phrase, players can trade/forge/assemble/mine

The game will end in 3 turns when 2 “Doomsday” card are dealt

Players that are able to build a spaceship can tally up the points and the most points wins!

Make allies or betray them! There could be 2 or more winners or no one wins!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Rawkahh! Whiz
boardgame.description:
Each player starts with 1pc 8 sided and 10 sided white dice
Vote for a player to go first and choose 1 of 2 actions

Re roll the Green or Red 10 sided dice, can re roll both
Call out A, B, or C and reveal a game card from deck

When the game card is revealed, all players can solve the equation by arranging the dice to provide the missing variables!

Players who got the right equation wins the card, they are disqualified for that round if they got it wrong
1 card = 1 point, players with most card wins

Games end when no more cards can be drawn or players can set the match point!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Rawkahh! Oops
boardgame.description:
Draw 4 characters and place on the side
A starting player can choose 1 of 3 actions
A. Redraw the 1 to 4 character cards
B. Challenge a player to win their card by playing the mini games
C. Flip a game card to start the fun!
If there is a matching character between the character card and game card, players can yell the character names/species to win the card
When 2 or more players yell the correct match at the same time, we can refer this as “collide”
These players need to quickly yell “Oops!” and yell the matching names again
The player who is left standing wins the card!
Players that yells the wrong match will be disqualified for that round and if they are disqualified for 3 rounds in a roll, they lose 1 card

1 card = 1 point, most point wins the games when no more card can be drawn!

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! – Henchmen Expansion
boardgame.description:
I love minions. They are indispensable cogs in the machine of my villainous ambitions — but they aren't too smart. You have to watch the minions all the time because otherwise they would screw up everything. I got sick and tired of this. I wish I had loyal assistants able to chasten the minions, twist the asteroids' tails, and bring me coffee in bed... Well, perhaps, that's not necessary.

But in our galaxy, everybody with a head on their shoulders fancies themselves a villain. Where to find quick-witted servants? Luckily, the League of Villains has come to aid just in time. They have assembled a portal to another dimension inhabited by best henchmen in the universe and vowed to open it once per season. I hope they are not lying. So all I can do now is wait! And rig the portal with explosives, of course, to prevent other villains from laying hands on what is rightfully mine!

The Henchmen Expansion for Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! gives you figures that are head and shoulders above ordinary minions. In the hands of a skilled villain, each henchman is able to reverse the course of the intergalactic battle!

At the start of the game, you shuffle the "Unstable Portal" card in the domination deck along with "Secret Facilities". Sooner or later, some player draws "Unstable Portal" , and when this happens, each villain takes a henchman card, which includes three abilities from which to choose. You can play any one of those abilities, then you place the henchman card in the discard pile.

The two upper abilities of a henchman card are played strictly in accordance with the minion ops rules. Furthermore, using a henchman is considered playing minion ops. Therefore, during your turn, you may either play one of the two upper henchman's abilities or a regular minion ops (along with any number of swift minion ops). As for the lower ability on a henchman card, it is played as swift minion ops. It's much weaker than any of the two upper abilities, yet comes in handy sometimes!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! – Nebula Expansion
boardgame.description:
— Dad, – a little minion asked, – what is shining so bright in the night sky? Is it a planet?

— No, it’s dark on the planets during the night – they are saving power to build Secret Projects.

— Perhaps, it’s a star?

— No son, we can’t see stars – the entire outer space is veiled by smoke traces left by Asteroids.

— So, what is it? – the kid insisted.

— They say, it’s an ancient space station flying in a nearby nebula, – mysteriously whispered father minion making his eyes even more round. – This is an artifact of proto-Villains who had lived long before the birth of our Master! This station contains countless treasures...

— New Secret Projects, Asteroids, and more Minions? – the kid supposed. In response, the father gave a pat on the son’s helmet and tousled his toy plasma gun hanging on the belt. A smart boy is growing! Just like his father.

Shuffle one or both Nebula Discovered! cards to the Domination deck. When a Villain draws Nebula Discovered! card from the deck, draw a Nebula card randomly from the Nebula pack of cards. Put three Asteroid-proof tokens near it.

While the Nebula card is in game, each Villain may launch Asteroids into the Nebula – instead of targeting other Villains.

When an Asteroid hits the Nebula, the Villain who has launched it gets exactly what is printed on the Nebula card. Then the Villain discards the Asteroid and removes one of the Asteroid-proof tokens placed near the Nebula. If it was the last remaining Asteroid-proof token, the Nebula card also goes to the discard pile.

A Villain may send a charged Asteroid into a Nebula as well. Such an Asteroid smashes the Nebula into pieces after executing its effect. Why do so? To prevent other Villains from getting benefits from that Nebula, of course!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Från ingenting till randig tandkräm
boardgame.description:
Litteral translation of title: "From nothing to striped toothpaste".

The game starts at nothing, before light and dark, and ends with the invention of striped toothpaste. A pedagogical game about the meaning of life and the purpose of humankind.

Cards follow a sequence a'la dominoes. A turn consists of the player who has the next card in sequence on hand placing it on the table. This player then has the choice of playing an event card, making players switch cards in various ways.

The goal of the game is to lay out all the cards, depicting a sort of evolution. The winner being the player who places the "striped toothpaste" card. Box contains 76 cards.

boardgame.name: Sidereal Confluence: Deluxe Resources
boardgame.description: Acrylic pieces which are shaped to show the relative values of each resource. Small cubes are replaced with diamonds, which when three are placed together make a hexagon. Large cubes are replaced with trapezoids, which when three are placed together make a hexagon. Octagonal barrels are replaced with hexagons. Thus the 3 small = 2 large = 1 octagon that must be taught to new players is immediately obvious.

boardgame.name: Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! – League of Villains Expansion
boardgame.description:
Dear Villains! Colleagues and Friends!

You are invited to participate in a fascinating experiment. As you already know, in a Galaxy far, far away, Superheroes have vanished. The local Villains were swift to use this opportunity and started a marvelous mayhem. They aren’t that experienced yet but have already laid hands on the antimatter and erected Secret Facilities on their planets.

Our duty is to enlighten them by setting the poor things on the right path of mutual destruction. Share your experience, teach disastrous tricks to them — and don’t forget to retreat before it gets too hot. As we always do.

Please submit three copies of your signed applications to the galactic cash register. The name of the lucky winner who is about to join the scuffle first will be announced separately!

Setup: Shuffle New Legend with the Domination deck. Deal one Run for Power! card to each player. Put the upper Legendary Villain card face-up. When a Villain draws New Legend card from the Domination deck, replace the Legendary Villain card with the next one.

Each Legendary Villain has a Salutation, Influence, and Superpower. Salutation comes into effect when the Legendary Villain enters the game. The Legendary Villain's Influence is in effect all the time while the respective Legendary Villain card is in play. Finally, each player may address the Legendary Villain for moral and physical support (activate his/her Superpower) by using Run for Power! card.

You may play Supervillain with League of Villains expansion as it is described in it's basic rules. Or... you may use it as an incredible source of new game modes!

League of Villains is the expansion bringing maximum variability to the game. In addition, it raises the replayability manyfold.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! – Lootable Planets Expansion
boardgame.description:
Not all Villains are as smart as I am. Frankly speaking, all these other Villains are much inferior to me, the great and one of a kind! But this is in our Galaxy. Recently another Galaxy has approached ours; it looks like the local Villains were pumpkin-headed enough to waste each other. Only Minions remain. The poor things wither without supervision on their desolate planets...

The scouts (those who managed to survive) report though that space self-defense forces are still active on some planets, while miniatures shaggy alien beasts were spotted on other planets, while somewhere else... these issues have to be dealt with. I have to send an Asteroid there.

Or two Asteroids. Or, even better, three. Somebody has to scavenge the scarce values left on these mysterious planets. Otherwise other Villains are going to loot everything...

Postscriptum. A special note for Asteroid firing pointers: “Shoot gently! The Asteroid must neatly penetrate the force field around the planet leaving all the valuables intact for further scavenging. Understood?”

During the game, Lootable Planets expansion provides an alternative. You may launch an Asteroid either into another Villain or into Lootable Planets. Then, in the beginning of your next turn, the Asteroid hits the target and... you find out what has happened.

Some cards of the Lootable Planets expansion are very useful. Hitting such a card is like hitting the jackpot! For example, May the Loss Be with You! card allows you to seize a random card from other Villain’s hand immediately, Backdoor Asteroid — to deliver a sudden blow to other Villain’s planet, while Star Shower — to launch two Asteroids at once.

Other cards of the Lootable Planets expansion are not that efficient. Sometimes the Minions point the Asteroid not very precisely and it smashes a half of the planet. The remaining half brings smaller loot.

Finally, there are two nasty cards — Ambush of Alien Hamsters and Assault on Black Hole. The Minions have launched the Asteroid... in a wrong direction. Assault on Black Hole simply ‘eats’ your Asteroid, which is logical — what else would you expect from a Black Hole?! But the Hamsters are worst of all. These tiny evil beasts retarget your Asteroid into you!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! – Reaction Expansion
boardgame.description:
Quick reaction is good not only in the Wild West (where the sole Secret Facility is Saloon, Colt Frontier Six-Shooter is used instead of Asteroids, while the only Minion is your horse). There are plenty of specialists in the space able to perform cunning tricks at breakneck speed! For instance... e-r-r-r... can’t find other examples... OK, for instance, me.

Oops, and another Villain — who used to rub hands foretasting some nasty success — finds himself among the ruins of his foolish hope. His Project failed to be completed on time, while the assault of his best Minion Operatives — successfully countered. Quick reaction rules!

Minion Ops with Reaction ability are played in response to certain actions of another Villain. These may be played during the other Villain’s turn, during your own turn (in theory), and basically at any time when the required condition is met.

In addition, you may play these Minion cards as regular Mobs. The Reaction ability pertains only to the Minion Ops.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Plop: Het Kabouterbos
Plop: La Forêt de Plop
boardgame.description:
Based on a popular Belgian TV-show (Kabouter Plop), Plop Het Kabouterbos is a game where players choose a character from the show and try to make a path from the forest to their homes. The first player to reach his home is the winner.

Each turn, players pick a card which can be:


a piece of road (to complete the player's own path or to mess up the competitor's path)
a shovel to remove a card from the board
a picknick basket (pass one turn)
a gnome cap (allows the player to move)


—user summary

boardgame.name: Apollo 20
boardgame.description:
Author's summary:

Did William Rutledge command a secret mission to investigate a derelict alien ship on the far side of the Moon in 1976? If so, what does that mean for the world of Delta Green?

I've finally had time to expand my thoughts on Apollo 20—a wonderful ghost story on the internet—and place it firmly in the world of Delta Green. Unleash it on your players as a great door into the mysteries of MAJESTIC, or as a dropped ball for the modern day Delta Green Program cleaning up an old, old, mess…
